subject: Are you Perl blogger?
header: Going back to the editorial of last week edition of weekly newsletter, it is still there in my head asking many questions. It is universal fact, Perl is no longer the favourite language among the youths in the college these days. I remember when I was first introduced to Perl in 1999, it was the most popular language. Being a Perl fan, I feel it is my responsibility to bring Perl back to discussion table. One way to do is to talk about Perl based project and share with audience of others language. I have noticed not many people blog about Perl as they used to in the past. Talking about blogs, I would like to thank The Weekly Challenge team for spreading the power of Perl. For record, in the last 138 weeks, the team have created and shared over 2000 blogs. I used to blog regularly in the past but now a days I hardly find time. Having said, I still do monthly report blog where I talk about Perl and other projects. I find doing live video is less time consuming than writing a blog. I did it for sometimes and then I stopped that as well, sorry. You can take a look my YouTube Channel if you fancy. I came across series of videos by Gabor Szabo teaching Perl. It is great source for someone new to Perl and explore with live action.

I remember, Dave Cross, wrote a blog talking about something not many people would speak about. I personally agree with him fully and believe knowing more than one programming languages help you as a programmer.I can tell from my own experience, I picked up Raku last year while participating the weekly challenge. Whatever little I know about Raku till date, I can tell it has helped me a lot. I use that knowledge to write better Perl program. Recently I started doing Python as well just the basics for now. So the question is, does knowing Raku or Python make me any less Perl programmer? I am still Perl programmer and all thought process still follow Perl rules. Perl is my first love and will remain so rest of my life. Even today, after more than 22 years, I find features that I never knew existed before, specially in the field of regex. I would like to give credits to Abigail for sharing the magical regex in Perl as part of his weekly contributions.

While talking about blog, how can I miss those who are doing great service on a regular basis? I would like to thank Flavio Poletti for blogging every day for months now. Also there is another name, Mark Gardner who does weekly blog. Similarly we have weekly stats by Miguel Prz.
Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.

chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 Amazon voucher by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one winner at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month. The monthly prize is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "JortSort" and "Long Primes". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 139

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Workdays" and "Split Number" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
entries.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 138

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Get to know about Paulo Custodio.
entries.title: Meet The Champion - Paulo Custodio

entries.author: abigail
entries.text: Abigail's blog has a nice bonus, I noticed, where you can live demo the solution. Really cool. Thanks for the support and encouragement.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Workdays

entries.author: abigail
entries.text: Abigail use of mathematical formula is fscinating. And then getting that translated into a subroutine is amazing. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Split Number

entries.author: arne_sommer
entries.text: Arne is one of the PWC members who I follow when it comes to Raku programming. His style of blogging apt for any new learner. Thank you for everything.
entries.title: The Workdays are Numbered with Raku (and Perl)

entries.author: cheok_fung
entries.text: Cheok-Yin is back with cool blog, collections of more than just one week. I loved the narrations. Keep it up great work.
entries.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #138 Task 1 and Some Previous Tasks on Calendar Date

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: What I like about Dave's blog is that he not only discuss the task but also gives bonus material related to the task. Incredible. Thanks for sharing.
entries.title: I Thank You For The Days: The Weekly Challenge #138

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: Flavio using 'subset' of Raku is nice and clean. Nice mathematical hack to get the end result. You are a great story teller too. Thanks for entertaining us every week.
entries.title: PWC138 - Workdays

entries.author: flavio_poletti
entries.text: A very interesting approach to the 'Split Number' task. I had to read the text twice to understand the flow. I loved the logic, something to keep in mind.
entries.title: PWC138 - Split Number

entries.author: james_smith
entries.text: James observation about the task is very unique. He has the ability to get to the bottom of each task and shares the knowledge. You really don't want to miss out. Thank you for sharing your experience with us.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #138

entries.author: laurent_rosenfeld
entries.text: A very compact solutions in Perl and Raku as always by Laurent. He always get to the point without wasting time. Keep up the great work.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Workdays and Split Number

entries.author: luca_ferrari
entries.text: Luca once again shares Raku and bonus solutions in PostgreSQL. Luca keeps things simple and I find it easy to follow. Thanks for sharing your knowledge.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: split working days

entries.author: luis_mochan
entries.text: Luis blog main attraction for me is the Perl one liner. It is not always easy to read but I like to challenge myself at times. Keep it up great work.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138

entries.author: roger_bell_west
entries.text: I liked how Roger picked Raku to talk about the Workdays task. Great example of code reuse. As always, thank you for your support and encouragement.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Split Work

entries.author: simon_green
entries.text: Simon is one of the few PWC members who always promote the weekly challenge on dev.to. Thank you for supporting us.

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.
